bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 2, 1929

div1.p: Agramonte thanks Kean for news of the pension bill, and expresses appreciation for Ireland's influence.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 2, 1929
div1.opener:
DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE
CALLE K. ENTRE 15 Y 17
VEDADO, HABANA February 2d, 1929.
P. file
Assoc'n Military Surgeons, U.S.
FEB 6 1929
Secretary-Editor's Office.
Col. J. R. Kean,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Col. Kean:
div1.p:
It was very nice of you to let me know of the
new Bill passed in the House last month, with reference to
recognizing the work of the Army Board by means of medals
and pensions. Of course, I am not very sanguine about it,
but all favors will be gratefully received.

I beg you to thank Gen. Ireland for whatever he has
done in the matter, as I highly appreciate the weight of his
influence and prestige in such a cause. Needless to say,
I am not indifferent to the proposed cutting down of the
pension, but I realize that there is nothing that can be
done in the matter; according to the Bill, everyone is ac-
corded the same reward, not taking into consideration that
many of the men, like the Spaniards themselves, were in
truth after the money they afterwards received and certain-
ly not inspired by any noble or altruistic sentiment, as was
the case with Kissinger and Moran.

Thank you again for letting me know, and with best regards,
I remain,
